text: I started working on this idea a while back - there currently is an app in the marketplace that will do this for properties but it is a one-time thing.  But I wanted my app to do more than that.  I have a working proto-type at this point but I still need to do a lot of work on it.  I will tell you the concept is doable but I have already put in a lot of work and still need a lot more before my app would be useable - even just by me.  The other thing is some things cannot currently be done - workflows for example.

To start with you need to learn to use the properties api.  Also you will need to set your source and destination portals - use the api to read properties from one portal and then write them to the other.  That kind of workflow.

I think I saw the exact same app you saw, either portal replicator or HubSpot to HubSpot (something like that) - but they wouldn't really do exactly what I needed (and expensive for a 1 time use, or the recurring wasn't going to be enough/etc.

From what you're saying it sounds like some kind of zapier type system to pull information from one HubSpot portal to zapier to new instance - or something of the sort (zapier I'm not sure would be able to do something like that, but was just my first thought)

Good Afternoon/Morning Everyone :coffee:

Guess what? We've just launched our `new Developer Documentation site` into public beta! :rocket: I can't wait for you to get your hands on this.

You can check it out by <https://developers.HubSpot.com/beta-docs/|visiting this link>. :click:

Here are some of the significant improvements we've made:
• Single source of truth across all of HubSpot's public APIs and each of their versions
• Overhauled search
• New design language 
• Holistic information architecture restructure 
• Responsively designed from the ground up
• New content for getting started
• Linking to individual endpoints
And so much more! We’d love for you to share with any HubSpot builder you know. Follow along and provide feedback over in <#C06S581J2AZ|developer-docs-beta>

I’m trying to export the users from HubSpot, however, it missing the Active/Inactive status. I checked the community, it’s upvoted 2 years ago, but looks like it still not support yet. I finally deleted all the Deactivated users in my back office to make sure, the API always return the Active users.
If have other options, please advise

Hi Team,
I'm testing some of HubSpot's CRM tools on my local browser and it the console has these errors-
```[Error] Blocked a frame with origin "<http://localhost:3000>" from accessing a frame with origin "<https://app.HubSpot.com>".  The frame requesting access has a protocol of "http", the frame being accessed has a protocol of "https". Protocols must match.


[Error] Blocked a frame with origin "<http://localhost:3000>" from accessing a frame with origin "<https://app.HubSpot.com>".  The frame requesting access has a protocol of "http", the frame being accessed has a protocol of "https". Protocols must match.


[Error] Blocked a frame with origin "<http://localhost:3000>" from accessing a frame with origin "<https://app.HubSpot.com>".  The frame requesting access has a protocol of "http", the frame being accessed has a protocol of "https". Protocols must match.```
Is there a way to bypass this? I tried adding  `localhost` to the Additional site domains section on Reports & Analytics Tracking but that does not work too

The errors you're encountering are related to the browser's same-origin policy, which is a security feature that prevents scripts from one origin from accessing or manipulating properties of a window or frame from another origin. This is in place to prevent cross-site scripting attacks (XSS).In your case, the local application running on <http://localhost:3000|http://localhost:3000> is trying to access frames from <https://app.HubSpot.com|https://app.HubSpot.com>, but the protocols do not match, causing the browser to block the request.Adding localhost to the "Additional site domains" section in the Reports & Analytics Tracking settings does not resolve the issue because the issue is not related to tracking but rather to the same-origin policy.One possible workaround to this issue is to use a tool like ngrok to expose your local application to the internet using a secure HTTPS connection. This would allow you to test the integration between your local application and HubSpot's CRM tools with the same protocol, thereby bypassing the same-origin policy issue. Hopefully that helps:open_hands:
